abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Perturbation of lipid homoeostasis is a major risk factor for cardiovascular disease (CVD), the leading cause of death worldwide. We aimed to identify genetic variants affecting lipid levels, and thereby risk of CVD, in Greenlanders. Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) of six blood lipids, triglycerides, LDL-cholesterol, HDL-cholesterol, total cholesterol, as well as apolipoproteins A1 and B, were performed in up to 4473 Greenlanders. For genome-wide significant variants, we also tested for associations with additional traits, including CVD events. We identified 11 genome-wide significant loci associated with lipid traits. Most of these loci were already known in Europeans, however, we found a potential causal variant near <jats:italic>PCSK9</jats:italic> (rs12117661), which was independent of the known <jats:italic>PCSK9</jats:italic> loss-of-function variant (rs11491147). rs12117661 was associated with lower LDL-cholesterol (β<jats:sub>SD</jats:sub>(SE) = −0.22 (0.03), <jats:italic>p</jats:italic> = 6.5 × 10<jats:sup>−12</jats:sup>) and total cholesterol (−0.17 (0.03), <jats:italic>p</jats:italic> = 1.1 × 10<jats:sup>−8</jats:sup>) in the Greenlandic study population. Similar associations were observed in Europeans from the UK Biobank, where the variant was also associated with a lower risk of CVD outcomes. Moreover, rs12117661 was a top eQTL for <jats:italic>PCSK9</jats:italic> across tissues in European data from the GTEx portal, and was located in a predicted regulatory element, supporting a possible causal impact on <jats:italic>PCSK9</jats:italic> expression. Combined, the 11 GWAS signals explained up to 16.3% of the variance of the lipid traits. This suggests that the genetic architecture of lipid levels in Greenlanders is different from Europeans, with fewer variants explaining the variance.</jats:p>

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The authors declare no competing interests.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The study was approved by the Commission for Scientific Research in Greenland (project 2011–13, ref. no. 2011–056978; project 2013–13, ref.no. 2013–090702; and project 2012-16/17, ref.no. 2017-12997) and was conducted in accordance with the ethical standards of the Declaration of Helsinki, second revision. All participants gave informed consent.

title: GWAS of lipids in Greenlanders finds association signals shared with Europeans and reveals an independent PCSK9 association signal
